content:
My current read on HTTP/3 is that it is the epitome of the William Gibson quote "The future is already here – it’s just not very evenly distributed"

HTTP/3 solves some very real issues with HTTP/2 (more on that later). Browser support is already really good but it's so strange to me that developer tooling seems so far behind.

- I have to use a custom build of curl to use http3.

- gRPC, a protocol known for pushing the world into HTTP/2 is flailing on committing to support HTTP/3 (except for, apparently, C#).

Yet 30% of web traffic is being served with HTTP/3. What the actual fuck?

I totally understand that quic and HTTP/3 are a big undertaking but it's just confusing how browsers, CDNs and load balancers can move so fast but some incredibly important tooling lags behind. Except for browsers, how do people test HTTP/3 endpoints?

HTTP/3 does solve a lot of problems for browsers and the web experience, but, for me, I am really excited at the possibility of using HTTP/3 to solve issues with gRPC (both in the frontend with gRPC-Web and the backend). I've had real issues with head-of-line blocking in the past and I really want the unambiguous solution to be adopting HTTP/3. I'm just a little restless because this all seems so close~~~
